posts.name: Ursa Major
posts.description: Ursa Major is a constellation in the northern sky, named after its resemblance to a great bear. It is one of the most recognizable constellations and contains the famous asterism known as the Big Dipper.

posts.name: Cassiopeia
posts.description: Shaped like a W or M, Cassiopeia is visible year-round but best seen in autumn and winter.

posts.name: Leo
posts.description: Representing a lion, Leo is prominent in spring and contains the bright star Regulus.

posts.name: Cygnus
posts.description: Also known as the Northern Cross, Cygnus is best seen in summer and autumn and features the bright star Deneb.

posts.name: Taurus
posts.description: Taurus: Characterized by the V-shaped Hyades cluster and the bright star Aldebaran, Taurus is visible in winter.

posts.name: Scorpius
posts.description: Located near the Milky Way, Scorpius is easily identifiable by its bright red star Antares and is best seen in summer.

posts.name: Gemini
posts.description: Representing twins, Gemini is prominent in winter and features the bright stars Castor and Pollux.

posts.name: Andromeda
posts.alsoKnownAs: The Chained Lady or The Chained Woman
posts.description: Home to the Andromeda Galaxy, this constellation is best seen in autumn and winter.

posts.name: Canis Major
posts.description: Contains Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky, and is visible in winter.
